comments.html: I don't think you need something proprietary, you can rely on any existing peer discovery mechanism (Bonjour?)
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: As of today, Apple seems to only use Multipath TCP for the Siri application. Contact Apple if you'd like to use it in your own application by filling a bug report on http://bugreport.apple.com, see http://tools.ietf.org/wg/mptcp/minutes?item=minutes-88-mptcp.txt
comments.name: Olivier Bonaventure

comments.html: But can this technology not be used in conjunction with something else (proprietary?) to improve transfers between iOS devices?
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html: In DCs, Multipath TCP allows you to better use the multiple paths that are available due to ECMP between any pair of servers. See http://inl.info.ucl.ac.be/publications/improving-datacenter-performance-and-robustness-multipath-tcp for a detailed discussion. Figure 20 shows the performance benefit in Amazon EC2
comments.name: Olivier Bonaventure

comments.html: Why would I use MP-TCP in DCs ?, instead would use packet spraying at each hop and take care of re-ordering at the destination?
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: See http://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=2591369 for a recent tutorial article on Multipath TCP. The implementation in the Linux kernel is available from http://www.multipath-tcp.org
comments.name: Olivier Bonaventure
